reviews.review_text: This is a puzzle game unlike any other. The clay animations are really well done and the whole concept of creating clones to solve puzzles, is a really neat idea. Add in the ability to swap between these clones and things become very interesting.  You'll get about 5-7 hours out of this game depending on how good you are with the puzzles. They are varied and challenging in the later stages as you become more comfortable with the gameplay.  The atmosphere is really moody, with a full spectrum of white light to pitch darkness. They really do a good job to make you feel like you're in space and completely isolated.  The Swapper is a genre defining leap for puzzle platformers. The developers have shown originality and passion, which are the first two things I look for in any game.

Even though  The Swapper  is only a four-hour puzzle game, it's still an atmospheric experience that both sci-fi fans and puzzle lovers will absolutely adore.  The Good: + Gorgeous clay-molded visuals with stunning lightingeffects. + A unique science fiction story. + Incredibly atmospheric, especially for a 2D puzzle game. + Phenomenal soundtrack. + Though puzzles bases on a clever clone-swapping concept that works perfectly...  The Bad: - ... but once you've completed the game there's not really any replayability. - Very short. Four hours should be enough to play through it.  The Ugly: - The visuals may take some getting used to, but in the end they perfectly fit the game's chilling atmosphere.  Final verdict: For a pricetag of 13.99€, you get unfortunately little content. Wait for it to go on sale (around 6.99€ looks like the perfect price), then definately pick this up if you love atmospheric games or puzzlers. 8/10

A great, unique game that I thoroughly enjoyed playing right until the very end. It proved to be an excellent puzzle platform game with excellent puzzles, excellent gameplay, a good atmosphere, and an intrigueing story. The art style is unique, but very well done as I think it suits the game and it's atmosphere. And to further add to that, I believe the soundtrack to be something pretty nice that also suits the atmosphere and setting of the game as well, with takes place aboard a space station in space. The puzzles in this game are definitely noteworthy and something not to think of lightly. They provide quite a challenge. Not an impossible, frustrating challenge, but a good challenge that really gets you to actually think and want to push to get the puzzle done. I had my fair share of stumps where some puzzles took me quite awhile to figure out, but I managed them in the end. Adding on to the puzzles, I also found gameplay to be another great feature of this game as well. Basically, the main feature and what this game revolves around is the Swapper device, which enables you to make clones, swap with them, etc. It's something fresh and interesting brought to the table of game mechanics. The story should also not be taken lightly either. A story if looked into enough by paying attention to the game, collecting logs, and actually thinking about it, is something that's pretty deep, good, and thought-provoking. I know it did have an effect on my emotions, which is something I really appreciate when a video game is able to do that to me.  This is a game that definitely deserves a lot of praise. It's a great, beautiful game that was not only a lot of fun to play, but also appreciate things like it's story, philosophical-related stuff, atmosphere, and more. I can easily see myself coming back to this game to play again down the road and would have no issues at all with another playthrough of it. It took me about a solid seven hours to complete the game, which I think was a decent length. Overall, my hat goes off to this game. A game I have no problem recommending to other people, as I believe it will provide a good challenge with a fun, but rewarding experience. Kudos to The Swapper!

I wanted to write an actual recommendation instead of single sentence I previously wrote. So yeah, I liked this game a lot. I'd like to boast that I completed the game without the help of any guides, but that would be a lie. And every time I had to reference a guide to complete a room, I always thought: 'well, durr, of course that's how it's done.' So, challenging but not cheap or too complicated. Worth the price if you are into these types of games, but I wouldn't be surprised to see it in a Humble Bundle at some point if you wait. And, holy crap, the ending!

A nice puzzle-platform (no shooting, no time to beat) where puzzles are based on your ability to create and control clones of yourself. Storyline is OK, graphics are nice and controls are very good. Mechanics of cloning may resemble Cloning Clyde but works in a different way:  - Clones are not created beside you, instead you aim your one-of-a-kind gun and 'shoot' to create them on the place you want (must have line of sight);  - Number of clones is always limited to 4 (you need to delete clones to be able to create other clones on other places);  - All clones mimick your moves, so you control everybody at the same time (some puzzles are based on this);  - If a clone dies, there's no problem, but if you die, you'll return to the last checkpoint;  - You can 'shoot' at a clone to 'transfer you soul' to that clone, so that the body you were becomes a clone and the clone you shot becomes you;  - Time slows down when you're aiming to create a new clone, which is very useful. If you're falling from a high place to certain death, you can slow down time, create a new clone on the ground and transfer your soul to it before you hit the ground thus avoiding death, or you can 'climb' through the air by creating clones above in the air, transfering your soul to it and quickly creating another clone even higher, soul tranfering again, repeat);  - There are some plates that invert gravity only for those who stepped on it, so that you'll sometimes have clones walking on the ground and others on the roof at the same time (again, some puzzles demand this);  The game may be a bit short, but mostly enjoyable. Two possible endings (decided on the last scene), so save often to see both without need to play all over again.  Recommended.

Only the highest praise I can give to the developers of The Swapper - an atmospheric puzzle/platforming exploration title that delivers an intense solitary experience, where as the protagonist[s] you must uncover the mystery behind the disappearances of Theseus Stations crew members - and the possible recovery of whatever project they were working on.  The plot may seem a bit vague at first (such as the withheld information on who your character is, and how/when the story begins), but eventually forms into clearer understanding. The questions that are asked and 'relatively' answered are: Who, what, when, why, and how? The Swapper is a story of very personal elements, which attempt to invoke self-thought and reflection. The game boasts a fantastic ambient soundtrack, gorgeous claymation visuals, and fluent mechanics. The puzzles you solve are made possible by cloning the player (the clones imitate the precise movement of the original), so careful movement and planning is required.   In the end The Swapper is a beautiful, artistic, and stellar creation and is absolutely a must have for any fan of the science fiction genre!

The first thing you'll likely notice about The Swapper is its incredibly unique visual style, which eschews computer generated animation in favor of stop motion animation and photographs of real life objects. Beyond that, the gorgeous visuals combine with an amazing ambient soundtrack and superb sound design to create a foreboding atmosphere, which suits the game's dark science fiction setting and story. And this game's more than just a pretty face, it's one of the most superbly designed puzzle experiences I've had in a while. The game's central mechanic is the swapper device of the title, which allows you to create and control up to four clones of yourself, and swap control between them. This fairly straightforward conceit is well-utilized in the game's many clever and satisfying puzzles. There's only two things - not even cons, really - that one should be aware of before buying this game, however. The first is that in spite of the Metroid-style map layout, it's not really a Metroidvania game. You don't gain new power ups, and there's not much in the way of branching paths or open-endedness, beyond simply being able to choose the order in which you solve certain puzzles, or skipping an especially tough one. Rather, the entire game is simply devoted to telling its story and exploring the possibilites of the swapping mechanic. Which I feel is to its credit, but it's something to be aware of anyway. Last, it's a short game. Like, super short. I finished it in four hours, if you have a lot of trouble then maybe call it five or six tops. Nor is it especially replayable, beyond taking the time to finish every single puzzle or find the ten secret terminals hidden throughout the game. It is highly satisfying for its length, however. Whether or not you should wait for a sale isn't something I'd want to decide for you, but one way or another I do highly recommend playing this game, it's a fantastic puzzle game that did a great job at making me feel really clever as I figured it out, and I enjoyed every minute of it.

A well done puzzle platformer. One of the more intriguing elements in the game is that they incorporate the philosophy of mind in the story. They use Daniel Dennett and David Chalmers as the protagonists for their respective positions (merely referred to by their last names in-game). Dennett does not believe in consciousness (soul in the game) and Chalmers is an advocate for consciousness (soul). Although the pro/con soul/consciousness debate is largely lacking the kind of robustness seen even in an elementary exposition of their positions in philosophical writing, it does a fair enough job to be provocative even for the veteran of philosophy. Additionally, experiencing it in an already mind-flexing puzzle game is icing on the cake. Therefore I don't dock them points for oversimplfying the philosophicals issues touched upon in the game. Even without the philosophical debate, the puzzles are enough to warrant the play through.

'You can die here, or you can do what you have to to go on.' These haunting words are all I could hear resounding my head during the final choice of the game The Swapper. Neither option was good, but they were both equally viable. So why was it such a big deal to me? Because The Swapper had swallowed me whole, and I was in it's world and this felt like a real decision.  I first saw this game earlier this year when it first launched on Steam. It's trailer intrigued me and I love puzzlers, so I added it to my wishlist. Come Summer Sale, my friend gifted the game to me when the price dropped. And now I have to thank him wholeheartedly because The Swapper is the one of the most intriguing, thought-provoking, puzzling, and, at many times, fun experiences of not only this year, but that I've yet played.  The story is set far into the future, and you have just arrived on the derelict Space Station Theseus. There is no indication to who you are, what the Station is there for, or where everyone went. You simply enter the Station and find the enigmatic Swapper device. And here lies the game's central gameplay mechanic and moral dilemma: you can create and swap into clones of yourself and use them to solve puzzles aboard the ship, however in doing so and exploring the station, you often have to kill the clones. The game then goes from there, taking you on a puzzle-filled tour of the station, as you investigate what went down on Theseus and follow the instructions of a mysterious woman that is also aboard. Both lead you on a quite a ride, all the way to the mind-blowing ending I referred to earlier.  I am pleased to report, that the puzzles are the best puzzles this game could have. It's the sort of puzzle that is Portal-esque in nature, simple but difficult simultaneously, but always logical. I only had to look up solutions twice, and both times I immediately facepalmed myself (likely where the developer's name originated from) for not realizing the solution that was staring me in the face. I was quite okay with this, because it was never frustrating at all when playing, and when I absolutely couldn't figure out to solve it, I'd just go to the other availiable puzzle to solve and return to that one later with fresh eyes. And when I did solve them, there was always that joy of 'Yes! I DID IT!' accompanying it.  The Swapper is a game I must insist you play. It's fascinating and thoughtful plot and well-crafted swapping mechanic and puzzles demand a playthrough. I don't often say a game simply has to be bought, but here it is. The Swapper is a wonderful adventure, puzzling from story to gameplay, that questions the true nature of the mind and soul, and the extent of what it means to have one.

Like the athmosphere, subtle light and color changes in the background, the mechanic sometimes tickles my brain more then I had expected. Achievements are a bust for me, though. Couldn't make any sense of them and didn't do one by chance. For all the slower paced people who don't need 64 people shooting at them, this will keep you happy for a while. I like it very much. A 'coldheartedly discarded clones' counter would have been nice :).

I actually had to take a break at one point because I hit the 'I swear I've tried every permutation' mark, but then you come back and see the new thing it requires, and it helps with the others. In retrospect, this is how the entire progression happens.  The Storyline is very well done, and digs into existentialism and metaphysics in a way that really makes you think about identity and what actually defines it. And ultimately you must decide what that definition is by the end of the game (and why I want to play it through again, beyond trying to find the other hidden areas).  The physics and perspective (creating not only a sense of 3d, but a well done transformation of a centerless 3D space onto the 2D UI.   One takeaway I'd give it is the way the achievements were done, but that's more of a Steam integration aspect, and not about the game itself. The other is how difficult it is to find hidden things, even with actively looking for them. It makes Capsized's hidden rooms seem obvious.  All in all I'd give it a 90+% Highly Recommended!

I generally wait until I finish a game to write any kind of review or tell anybody about it. But it bares noting at this point that I'm completely mesmerized by the puzzles, the game mechanics, and the atmosphere...  Atmosphere  From the get go, the music that plays is light and dramatic. The lights are hazy, and feel just as dangerous as the darkness, revealing more questions than answers. What tidbits I've been fed of the story so far are intriguing and thought provoking. All of this is so rewarding at a time where so many games fail to grab my attention with their environment.  The only thing that really bothers me  is that movement is a binary function, and sometime I wish I could just walk slowly into a room, scan it with my headlamp, and cautiously step forward into the ruins.  Mechanics  The creative uses for the clone gun are posed upon you in such a way that, instead of telling you and holding you buy you hand, once you need them, you'll be forced to figure it out. It's a small task, but so much more rewarding than throwing a few garbage puzzles at you and blatantly telling you how to handle it. Progressing further requires you to finish so many puzzles, but it feels more like you're exploring and collecting necessary supplies to venture further into the unknown, to fufill a task you've no idea how to do, or even what it is. Your character feels blank, and becomes a mystery itself when it's tied to the way you navigate your environment with the clone gun. A moral implication pooling in the back of my mind.  Buy this thing...  This is a game that does a fantastic job of handling that sort of invisible hand of guidance that pulls you in to a story rich, puzzler. As of right now, I'm overwhelmed by that sensation of experiencing something that holds a mystery worth solving. It's a feeling I don't seem to get too much anymore in games that feel like a regurgitated mess of textures and lens flares and quadrillion dollar budgets. I feel like this could exist. It does exist. And I'm going back there now.  Edit: Finished this game. A handful of puzzles really got into my head, but none moreso than the ending. What a beautiful story.

I've played so many games that I'm starting to become jaded, thinking I've played it all. Dishonored is just another Deus Ex. Skyrim is just another Morrowind. GTA5 is just another GTA3. Rock band is Amplitude. But...The Swapper is The Swapper.  I finally installed it from my owned-for-months-but-never-played steam library shelf, and I'm glad I did. The mechanic the developer introduces is very unique, and they continually throw variations of the environment at you to bend your mind in different ways.  That said, your loadout is set from the get go. You don't earn to ability to make more clones or jump higher. Thankfully you don't need that, and knowing that you have everything you need to solve a puzzle makes you face it more confidently. Compare that with some MetroidVanias that have you second guessing if you're tooled enough to solve a problem, backtracking, and ultimately having several puzzles that feel like dead ends. There are no dead ends here, just your mental inflexibility. Keep stretching, and you'll get satisfaction from every puzzle.  On the downside, the achievements are pretty ridiculous. Spoiler, though I doubt anyone will achieve all of them through diligence alone:   They are all hidden consoles, very hidden, that give more storyline. None of the achievements are related to decisions you make or don't make throughout the game, or the number of puzzles you solve. Remember in Wolfenstein 3D when you had to 'open' every single wall texture to see if there are secret stashes behind them? You'd have to do that same approach here to have a chance at finding all the consoles. Back when I was nine years old I had the time or the patience for that crap. Now, I just youtubed them.    To end on a positive, the game is pretty philosophical. You can ignore it if that's not your thing, but if it is, get ready for some serious ethics, and to ponder: what is conciousness?

Wait, how have I not reviewed this yet? I think someone jostled my being into forgetting.  This game is splendid. Artistically, musically, narratively, and in terms of design. It's clever and smart and will make you pick your brain to reach its conclusion, a conclusion which is very much worth seeing. However, this also makes it difficult to describe without spoiling the experience much, so I'll try to keep it to the basics.   The game begins with your standard amnesiac trope, but quickly unfurls from this seemingly uninteresting setup as you're ejected from a station to an alien world and make your way back to the station to simply figure out what's going on. As is standard with space stations in games, they're  never  working as intended, but instead of going with common horror fare, this game follows the path of mystery, uncovering what the station was researching, where it was in relation to the rest of civilization, and so on.   As it does so, the game introduces increasingly captivating concepts, both in the narrative and the gameplay, as you have to work out how to manipulate clones synced to your movement to solve a variety of puzzles. To a degree, both may also prove difficult to wrap your head around and work through, but that makes it all the more satisfying when you figure it out (or think you've figured it out) without resorting to a guide or someone else's interpretation.   Go in with ignorance, and devise your satisfaction. =D

The gameplay of The Swapper surrounds a device that your unidentified astronaut carries after having located it at the beginning, roughly, of the game. With this device you can created four clones of yourselfthat mimic your movements. Move left and the clones moves left; jump and the clones jump. The trick, then, is generally one of placement of the clones to achieve your goals (generally accessing orbs to unlock new areas): place a clone too close to a ledge and it could plummet to its doom or become stuck, or end up completely useless as you move your astronaut and each clone mimics those movements. The player can also 'swap' with the clones (thus 'Swapper' device), thus changing which astronaut that you are directly controlling, into one of the other clones. Pressing buttons or moving boxes at the right moment to achieve the goal of each room is dependant upon careful positioning to allow each clone to peform the task that is required of it.  The joy of the puzzles is that all of the positioning and swapping pays off in such a way that there is an immediate satisfaction in having put all of the pieces into place. The moment of recognizing a solution, and make no mistake here that it is RECONIZING the solution as dumb luck will almost never occur, came very close to making me yell 'A-ha!' on at least a couple of occasions. The challenge of these rooms increases at a steady pace, with the initial sections being fairly simple affairs and the later rooms significantly more difficult. They are never impossible; but neither does there seem to have been the slightest thought put toward holding the player's hand. The developers seemed to work with the idea that once the basics were taught in the earlier, more simple rooms that the player should have all that he/she requires to play through the rest of the game. This was refreshing: here was a game that expected that players were, at some level, capable of learning the fundamentals and from their own mistakes.  What I rarely expect out of a puzzle game is a story. In those times where stories do exist in the puzzle genre they have a tendency to have the simplicity of Super Mario Bros. This is not a fault: it's just not common to the genre, so I do not go in with any expectations. The most that I expected here was 'Here's your astronaut. He has a cloning device. Now go.' It is the story of an unidentified astronaut (the player's character) who is unceremoniously ejected out of an airlock in the opening cinematic of the game. This character is progressing through the base that he/she eventually finds his/her way back to (I'm not spoiling anything here: 99% of the game takes place on this base. The planetary portion serves only as a tutorial) in an effort to find out what happened, and how to get off of the base given the apparent lack of usable ships (and the planet below is hardly habitable by all indications). This is very much an abbreviated version of the basics: there is more to the story, but it's best to experience that without it being entirely spelled out and spoiled. The Swapper's story has a heavy ethical bend; and while the main points of ethics and morality are not particularly subtle within the context of the experience, what I was surprised by was the specifics of the story were largely left up to the player to figure out. Writing in games (and other mediums, but we are discussing a computer game) tend to leave little room for interpretation or show much faith in the player to grasp what is going on without very specifically telling them what is happening from one moment to the next and why. Exceptions are rare, and I was pleasantly surprised to find that The Swapper was one of those exceptions. The developers showed a lot of faith in the players to be able to piece together what is happening and why, the specifics of who the astronaut is, the nature of the base, what the Head Watcher is and what it does, without ever DIRECTLY stating it. This leaves some room for interpretation, of course, and while that is always fun to some degree I was most pleased that I wasn't being treated like a fool who cannot even tie his own shoes without specific instruction. The only downside to the story, and this is somewhat subjective as it did not bother me at all, but I could see it bothering some, is that the player has to go looking for it to some degree. There are terminals as asteroids that provide the details, as well as some sequences that are played out with characters and communications. The terminals and asteroids have to be sought out, and new asteroids tend to crop up after certain points in the game forcing the player to look over the map screen at previously visited areas to see if something new has popped up. Again, this did not bother me; but seeking these points to provide the full story could be a bother to some.  On audio there is little to say. This is not a criticism; it is only fact. The game consists primarily of isolation in a seemingly deserted base in outer space. Little in the way of life, little in the way of functioning equipment. In that context there should not be a lot of obvious sound effects, and those that do exist are effective. The music is good in that it is well suited to background noise. What little voice acting exists is effective; and while ‘effective’ is often used as a synonym for ‘not great’ it is very fitting here given the environment that is presented.  The visuals have a refreshing look to them, in spite of the gloom and isolation. Most games' visuals are clearly identifiable as digital works: they look like they were developed inside of a computer. At their most realistic there are still obvious giveaways; and even when cel shading takes place to resemble hand-drawn animation it is still clear that this is simply a style that is being used by those who are sitting at their computers crafting the details. The Swapper's environments and characters were created by hand using various crafting materials, and what would seem to be primarily clay-based. I say 'seem to be' on account of my having done admittedly little research into the exact details of its craftsmanship; but what I did read mentioned clay specifically each time, and then glossed over any other materials which I could only imagine were used as little more than accents or as a means to hold things together. While hand crafting does not immediately translate into something that is somehow superior by its nature (saying so would be silly) it does give The Swapper a unique appearance when help up to other games. What was crafted was well made, with the environments being appropriately details for the most part. A few of the rooms looked somewhat barren; and while this may be realistic it was jarring when compared to so many of the other rooms and sets that were utilized. Much was dark of course given the semi-functional and abandoned nature of the station upon which the game takes place; but even those darker areas still had some details that emphasized a level of care. It looked mostly great, and served to convey the haunting mood and accentuate the story in a 'something has happened here' sort of way.  It isn't often that a game surprises me. I am not speaking here of twists in the narrative or scares, but rather the fundamental style and make up of the experience. This was The Swapper's greatest strength for me. I enjoy a good puzzler, and the atmosphere and music was seemingly strong. It all felt like a package that I was confident that I would enjoy. I'm extremely pleased that I took the chance: so much of the game simply clicked on multiple levels for me: in the satisfaction of the gameplay (which is crucial since this is a game, after all), and in the atmosphere and story. The game may not go down as the finest ever made, but it is one of the most satisfying experiences that I have encountered in years.
